Graphical abstract The design and fabrication of TMNs for electrocatalytic applications is promising due to the integration of multiple structural and compositional advantages of the TMNs which enhances their performance and durability. The advancement and growth of nanotechnology lead to realizing new and novel multi-metallic nanostructures with well-defined sizes and morphology, resulting in an improvement in their performance in various catalytic applications. The trimetallic nanostructured materials are synthesized and designed in different architectures for energy conversion electrocatalysis. The as-synthesized trimetallic nanostructures have found unique physiochemical properties due to the synergistic combination of the three different metals in their structures. A vast array of approaches such as hydrothermal, solvothermal, seed-growth, galvanic replacement reaction, biological, and other methods are employed to synthesize the trimetallic nanostructures. Noteworthy, the trimetallic nanostructures showed better performance and durability in the electrocatalytic fuel cells. In the present review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent strategies employed for synthesizing trimetallic nanostructures and their energy-related applications. With a particular focus on hydrogen evolution, alcohol oxidations, oxygen evolution, and others, we highlight the latest achievements in the field. Keywords Trimetallic nanoparticle Electrooxidation Electrocatalysis Alloy Energy conversion 1 Introduction Owing to their unique physicochemical and electrical properties, engineered metal-based nanostructures have widely been applied in a different scope of applications, including catalysis [1–5], electronics [6], environmental remediation [7], energy conversion [8], cosmetics, and food packing [9]. In particular, the controllable synthesis of these metal-based nanostructures with unique morphologies, precise size, and optimum surface area endows them to be catalytically active for several reactions [10]. Of compelling interest is the trimetallic nanostructures (TMNs) containing three different metals with distinct morphologies. Until now, these nanostructures have been demonstrating excellent performance in many reactions including, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [11], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [12], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [13], alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR) [14], and formic acid oxidation [15]. Given a number of interesting features in this ternary system, the trimetallic nanostructured catalysts have been demonstrating superior catalytic activity and reasonably higher stability, which had surpassed the benchmarks in many examples. It can be anticipated that designing more complex alloys (from mono to ternary) system provides more possibilities to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of the TMNs via tuning the metal compositions, proportions, size, and morphology [16]. Therefore, the designing of such trimetallic nanoarchitectures using earth-abundant metals could be regarded as a hot topic of research in the field of electrocatalysis. Generally, the TMNs are a fascinating class of nanomaterials that consists of alloys/clusters of three different metal atoms in their reduced form. A rationally designed TMNs with a well-controlled size, surface area, morphology, and compositions afford superior catalytic performances in many reactions [17]. In contrast with mono and bimetallic nanomaterials, they have drawn the attention of many researchers due to their tunable properties and drastically improved catalytic performances. Inspired by their fascinating properties, different scholars have attempted to rationally design novel ternary metal alloys with unique morphologies. The frequently employed synthesis strategies such as reduction method, seed growth strategy, solvothermal method, and galvanic replacement reactions (GRR) have brought interesting progress in designing and fabricating more functional material with extraordinary morphologies and excellent performances. For instance, the TMNs with different morphologies such as nanomeshes [18], nanosheets [19], nanoframes [20], and nanocages [21] that owned promising performance for catalytic oxidation of organics have already been communicated. On top of that, the trimetallic system could be used as a versatile platform for developing a material system that contains novel metals (such as Pt and Ir) in a trace amount, bringing interesting features in deriving some catalytic reactions [22]. The recent studies, for example, have unveiled the exciting catalytic performance of novel metal (such as Pt and Ir) based ternary metal alloys for HER, OER, and ORR [23]. Moreover, the possibilities of tuning composition of the TMNs afford flexibility for stemming an overall change in the physicochemical property due to the involvement of the third metal. Also, several features such as tuning electronic property, change in the d-band center, electronic charge shift, and overall performance can be manipulated via employing such a ternary structure [24]. For example, the modification of electronic structure has been achieved via alloying Pt with other metals such as Cu, Au, and Co. According to the Hammer-Nørskov reactivity model, when metals with larger lattice constant (like Pt) are alloyed with metals possessing smaller lattice constant (such as Co, Au, and Cu), there will be a downshift in the d-band center of Pt. As a result, the d-band center contributes to the overall electronic charge transfer, which likely enhances the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity of TMNs compared with their monometallic and bimetallic counterparts [24,25]. Recently, Wang et al. demonstrated that electrons transfer from Cu and Pd atoms to Pt atom result in the downshift of the d-band center of Pt due to the lower electronegativity of Cu (1.90 eV) and Pd (2.20 eV) than Pt (2.28 eV). The metals with higher work function can accept charges from the metals with a lower work function, resulting an overall increase in Fermi level [26]. Applying various supporting materials to the TMNs plays a key role in improving the catalytic activity of the nano-catalyst. The interaction of the active metal phases with the supporting materials also plays a key role to improve the performance of the nano-catalysts [27,28]. For example, the electrocatalytic alcohol oxidation performance of AuPtAg TMNs was enhanced due to the pivotal role by the second metal which supplies hydroxy species (at lower potentials) to complete the oxidation and remove adsorbed intermediates like CO. This would be challenging in the case of monometallic catalyst since the poisoning of the catalyst surface happens as the reaction proceeds (scheme 1 ). As for the trimetallic system, the change of the d-band center results into increase in the Fermi energy. In the majority cases, the TMNs will bind the OH group more weakly than the metal NPs [29]. Upon the formation of the core shell, the TMNs showed superior catalytic activity than the corresponding mono and bimetallic nanoparticles (NPs) due to the modification of properties caused by the third metal [30]. Thus, the need for multi-component NPs is due to their impressively high exposed active surface areas, efficient electronic and synergistic effects, provide a greater freedom in tuning the band gap for improving their catalytic property [31], and durability leads to carry out for electrocatalytic applications like in methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) [32], Ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) [33], HER [34], formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR), ORR, OER [35,36] The rationally designed interfaces among the three different metals are beneficial to improve the catalytic properties of the TMNs. For instance, PtCuRh nanowires (NWs) exhibited a nearly 1.35- and 1.76-fold enhanced mass activity (MA) compared to PtCu NWs and Pt/C, respectively, during the EOR. As a result of the change in the d-band center in Pt and ultrafine structure of the NW, the electronic interaction in the TMNs was improved, resulting in an overall improved performance [37]. Similarly, a highly active and stable trimetallic PtSnBi nanoplates demonstrated excellent performance for FAOR electrocatalysis [38]. These nanoplates showed 6/39/39-fold improvement in their MA, compared to their respective bimetallic counter components, PtBi nanoplates/PtSn NPs/Pt/C, respectively. The combined electronic and geometric effects account for the observed improvement in the catalytic activity. The charge transfers from Sn and Bi to Pt with a lower charge value of Sn than the PtSn tailored to an optimized value of △GHCOO*. Benefited from their unique electronic and structural advantages, the trimetallic nanostructures in the aforementioned studies unveiled the family's peculiar and interesting features, suggesting their future development in the field of catalysis. In another recent study by Kuroki et al. [39] reported chemically ordered PtFeNi TMNs that was annealed at 800 °C. The TMNs showed an improved catalytic activity and durability towards ORR than the mono and bimetallic systems due to the chemically ordered superlattice structure of the TMNs electrocatalyst. Given the ever-increasing research interest and promising potential in their catalytic properties, it is ideal and timely to offer a comprehensive overview of the latest development of the synthesis strategies and catalytic applications of TMNs. Until recently, very few review papers are communicated regarding the synthesis and potential application of the TMNs, while most of them are focused on the health, environmental, or general catalytic applications [40–47]. However, in these reviews, the latest development in the electrocatalytic applications of these TMNs was not highlighted, and some important synthesis methods and growth mechanisms are lacking. In this review, we summarize the design, fabrication, and catalytic application of various TMNs. The recent development of TMNs for catalyzing some selected reactions such as HER, OER, ORR, AOR, and FAOR are briefly discussed. Finally, the major challenges are highlighted, and the conclusion is offered based on the latest development in the field. We hope that our review could guide researchers to rationally designing various ternary structures with unique morphologies for different applications. 2 Synthesis strategies The unique physical, chemical, and catalytic properties displayed in bimetallic nanomaterials compared to their monometallic counterparts motivated various researchers to design trimetallic architectures. To date, the TMNs are fabricated using different strategies, which can be grouped under the top-down and bottom-up approaches. The bottom-up approaches are accompanied by the building up of atoms or molecules to the required nanostructures, and it is preferable due to its simplicity, very cheap, and scalability. In this section, we will provide a brief overview of the synthesis methods that have been employed for fabricating different types of TMNs. The Pt-based TMNs such as PtFeRu [48], PtVFe, PtRuCo [48], or PtRuMo [49], have been synthesized for various applications, including alcohol oxidation, ORR, and HER, as summarized in Table 1 [50]. The TMNs are synthesized based on the framework of the electronic effect of bimetallic NPs having core/shell architectures. Thus, the three metals produce the three-layered core/shell architectures, which are expected to have an effective and successive electronic effect and charge transfer, as shown in Scheme 2 [51]. 2.1 Galvanic replacement reaction (GRR) Since the catalytic activity of the TMNs is strongly dependent on their size, morphology, surface, electronic, and structural effects, shape-controlled synthesis of the NPs with abundant surface area and exposed facets are an utmost interest. Recently, TMNs with fascinating morphologies (nanowires, nanoflowers, nanocubes, nanodots, and nanodendrites) and surface areas are synthesized and studied for electrocatalytic applications [52]. In recent studies, the GRR method has been demonstrated as an attractive and facile approach for the fabrication of TMNs. The synthesis process is based on the sequential GRRs between the sacrificial template and other metal precursors [53]. Hollow, core–shell, nanocubes, nanotubes, nanoframes, nanorattles, nanocages, and porous structure TMNs with controlled size and morphology have been prepared using GRR [54]. The composition can be precisely controlled by adjusting the molar ratio between the sacrificial template and other metal ion preconditions [53]. The sacrificial template metal, which has more negative reduction potential, becomes a reducing agent at the anode, and the other metal act as an oxidizing agent at the cathode. The shape of the TMNs usually depends on the first sacrificial template. Thus, metals with lower reduction potential such as Co2+, Ni2+, and Cu2+ fabricated first than the noble metals (Pt, Au), which have higher reduction potential [55]. In contrast to other techniques, the GRR has some drawbacks. It often requires substrate (templates) to obtain the desired architecture, which usually increases production cost. In addition, the experimental procedures are complex and time-consuming. Therefore, there is a need to develop a template-free GRR process for nanostructure synthesis [56]. The nucleation of the metals and controlling the growth kinetics in the presence of three metal precursors is also challenging [57]. Recent work by Shviro et al. [58] proposed the formation of hallow octahedral and cuboctahedral PtNiAu ternary nanocrystals using a GRR by Au(III). The third metal plays a vital role during the formation of the hallow TMNs through the diffusion of Au onto the Pt-Ni bimetallic frameworks. Additionally, the nucleation of Au on the surface of the particle together with Ni etching is taking place in the first stage of the reaction. The diffusion of the Au is allowed to overgrowth and stabilized in the presence of the oleylamine (stabilizer or reducing agent), then a transfer agent in GRR in a biphasic medium is used to promote the metal overgrowth [59]. Ni etching to the Ni(II) molecular species happened preferentially at the Ni-rich part leading to the segregation of Ni on the {111} facet regions could confirm the successful fabrication of noble metal-rich nano frame. The attachment of Au(III) on NiPt4.8 polyhedral species conveys a further model of the etching mechanisms regioselectivity, as shown in Fig. 1 (a) [58]. Similarly, trimetallic Pt–Pd–Ni octahedral nanocages can be formed in the same fashion [60], as shown in Fig. 1(b). Song and Chen [61] synthesized the Ag@AuPt TMNs via a two-step interfacial GRR of 1-hexanethiolate-capped silver NPs (AgC6) with gold(I)-thiomalic acid (Au(I)TMA) and platinum (II)-hexanethiolate complexes. In the first step, the AgC6 NPs were allowed to form a monolayer carried out at the air–water interface, and the water-soluble Au(I)TMA was injected into the water phase to form the bimetallic AgAu NPs. The bimetallic NPs were then immersed into acetone solution containing Pt(II) complexes to obtained the Ag@AuPt TMNs. Recent works by Ahn and Qin [62] reported the synthesis of multi-metallic nanoscale cage cubes of Ag-Au-Pt using GRR by confining Ag's drilling to each side of the nanocube of Ag enclosed by Ag-Au alloy frames. Then the Ag@Ag-Au core-frame nanocube is transformed into Ag@Ag-Au-Pt concave cube when Pt precursor H2PtCl6 is added in the presence of celyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC). Finally, the Ag@Ag-Au core-frame is changed to Ag-Au-Pt cage cube via GRR (Fig. 2 (a)). The transformation of the Ag-Au-Pt cage cube, as confirmed by the scanning electron microscope (SEM) image, showed cavities on the side of the faces. High-angle annular dark-field scanning-SEM (HAADF-SEM) further confirmed the presence of concaveness on the side of the face, and the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping resolves the spatial distribution of the elements (Fig. 2(b–d)). Similarly, Pei et al. [63] successfully fabricated uniform and highly open nanoframe structure of Ir-Cu for OER by a one-pot synthesis approach. The Ir-Cu were synthesized using IrCl3 3H2O and Cu(acac)2 precursors and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) in oleylamine, oleic acid, and octylamine, respectively. Thus, the synthesized Ir-Cu nanoframe was used as a template to synthesis Ir-Cu-Au nanoframe by the GRR. The uniformity and highly open features of the nanoframes were confirmed by transmission electron microscope (TEM) and HAADF-STEM image, respectively (Fig. 2(e, f)). Gruzeł et al. [64] successfully synthesized PtNiSn NPs from Ni-core/Pt-frame via GRR of Ni by Sn. It was demonstrated that the average composition of the nanoframe was Pt11Ni6Sn3. In the first step, reduction of Sn ion takes place after Ni oxidation happened; in the second step, oxidation of Ni and reduction of Sn ions co-occurred. Based on the HAADF and STEM images and EDS mapping results, Ni core dissolves and Ni atom diffuse out of the NP followed by Sn deposition in 4 min. After 32 min, the GRR was stopped to avoid blocking Pt active sites by an excess of Sn that was deposited on the frame (Fig. 2(g, h)). 2.2 Co-reduction method Nowadays, different approaches are followed to fabricate TMNs and their composites in different shapes in order to modify their catalytic activities. The co-reduction method is simple to synthesize mono, bi, and trimetallic nanostructures. The metal precursors are dissolved in a suitable solvent, and reducing agents are added to convert the metals to a zerovalent state. However, impurities among the core and mixed shell metals are the main disadvantage of the co-reduction method. For example, Au core has been mixed with Pd and Pt shell that was not separated into two independent layers in the Pd and Pt shells in the Au@PtPd TMN [65–67]. Xie et al. [68] synthesized AuAgPt hetero-nanostructure via a co-reduction method using L-ascorbic acid (L-AA) as a reducing agent. The as-obtained nanostructure exhibited a uniform morphology with an average particle size of 80 nm employing the Au nanorod as a seed for electrocatalyst. Ye et al. [69] prepared Cu/Au/Pt TMNs using the co-reduction method through the reduction of HAuCl4, CuSO4, and K2PtCl4, with the presence of NaBH4 at room temperature in a one-pot synthesis. The TMNs were developed for biosensing and theranostics applications. A porous trimetallic Au@Pd@Ru NPs synthesized by successive sacrificial oxidation of cobalt NPs (Co NPs) were delivered as efficient and one-pot synthesis at room temperature as shown in Fig. 3 (a) below [70]. The TMNs were prepared by a stepwise displacement of Co NPs. Porous Au, Au@Pd NPs has been prepared first, followed by the preparation of Au@Pd@Ru. The porosity and presence of the metals have been confirmed by TEM, Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images, and EDS results. Wang et al. [71] prepared shape-controlled PtPdCu trimetallic nanocrystals for electrocatalytic application using a co-reduction method. The nanocrystals are prepared in the form of porous nanocubes and nanodendrites using surfactants and water as the only solvent. The Pt, Pd, and Cu precursors in an aqueous solution are allowed to reduce. Sarmoor et al. [50] also used a simple reduction method to engineered PtSnZn nanosheet thin film for alcohol oxidation. Reduction of organometallic precursors such as [PtCl2(cod)] (cod = cis, cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene) and Sn(CH3)4 complexes, and Zn(acac)2 complex at toluene–water interface are used. The Pt and Sn showed face center cubic (FCC) lattice structure whereas Zn appeared as hexagonal close packing (HCP). 2.3 Solvothermal/hydrothermal methods The hydrothermal and solvothermal methods are similar; the only difference is the use of the aqueous solution in hydrothermal and nonaqueous solution in the solvothermal method during the growth procedure. They are simple and facile in their operation but performed at above ambient temperature and pressures [72,73]. The solvothermal/hydrothermal approaches are relatively environmentally benign, consume low energy, and performed in a liquid environment to synthesize the required morphology and controlled the size of the materials being produced. Apart from this, the method is employed with higher pressure and minimum loss of nanomaterials, and theprocedureiswellcontrolledthroughliquid-phaseormultiphasechemicalreactions. On the other hand, these methods have disadvantages because of the high temperature, pressure, corrosive resistance, and high-cost materials are required. The determination of the exact reaction equilibria is also difficult due to the presence of numerous species in the nucleation and growth steps [40,74]. As for the growth of TMNs, this method is acknowledged by many scholars in the field. For instance, Wang et al. [26] synthesized PtPdCu nanowires possessing a polycrystalline structure using a one-pot solvothermal route. With the help of polyvinylpyrrolidone and KBr as reducing and morphological controlling agents, respectively, the PtPdCu nanowire was obtained and further used as an anode in the MOR and FAOR. Similarly, PtCuCo trimetallic alloy NPs having hollow structures have been prepared using glycine and Ni2+ mediated hydrothermal treatment of Co3O4, Cu2+, and Pt2+ in aqueous solution as demonstrated in Fig. 3(b) [25]. The formation of the PtCuCo TMNs was dependent on the co-reductant glycerin, Co3CO4, and Ni2+ templates. 82% yield of the hollow TMNs has been obtained with rough surface and appears to have multiple defects that serve for its catalytically active. 2.4 Biological method The properties of multi-metallic nanostructures are different from the monometallic and metal NPs in terms of catalytic application and synthesis procedures. Though few reports are available on plant and microorganism-mediated synthesis of NPs, the TMNs are formed via a successive reduction mechanism. More investigation and researches are required to know the appropriate synthesis protocols and conditions [75]. Recently, the biologically derived synthesis, which can be obtained from renewable sources such as plant extracts, microorganisms, enzymes, and waste materials, are acting as reducing, capping, and stabilizing agents that could replace the physical and chemical methods [17]. The biological method is easy, cost-effective, and eco-friendly than the other methods. However, it has drawbacks related to the reproducibility, yield, size/morphology control of the nanomaterials, and unknown reaction mechanisms [76,77]. Dlugaszewska and Dobrucka [78] use a green and bioinspired method to synthesized Au/Pt/Ag TMNs using Lamii albi flos extracts. The TMNs (35–40 nm) was applied for antibacterial activity against gram-positive and gram-negative bacterial and it shows a promising result. Rao and Paria [79] used mixed plant extracts Aegle marmelos leaf (LE) and Syzygium aromaticum bud extracts (CE) to synthesized Ag-Au-Pd TMN. The concurrent reduction of AgNO3, HAuCl4, and Na2PdCl4 took place under controlled conditions using the plant extracts with glucose acting as a reducing and stabilizing agent and oxidized to gluconic acid. The Ag-Au-Pd TMNs was prepared in 10 min with an average diameter of ~8 and ~11 nm corresponding to LE and LE + CE extracts, respectively. Vaseghi et al. [80] used a green method to synthesize Cu/Cr/Ni NPs using aqueous extracts of Eryngium campestre and Froriepia subpinnata. Eryngium campestre (EC-TMNs), Froriepia subpinnata (FS-TMNs), and EC + FS mediated TMNs for antimicrobial activity against E. coli and S. aureus. In another study, Mishra et al. [81] used Astragalus membranaceus root extract to fabricate AuFeAg TMNs. The as-biosynthesized NPs catalyst was used to synthesized α, β and β, β-dichloroenones from the cyclic diazodicarbonyl compounds. The hybrid catalyst was convenient and reused several times without significant loss of its activity. Basavegowda and coworkers [82] synthesized FeAgPt trimetallic nanocatalyst using Platycodon grandiflorum root extracts for the reduction of 4-nitroaniline (4-NA) to p-phenylenediamine via ultra-sonication for dye removal application. The root extract is rich in proteins, lipids, triterpenoids, and saponins which are responsible for the reduction of the metal ions. 2.5 Seed growth method The seed growth approach is a two-step synthetic strategy where the nucleation and growth of the particles are carried separately. Using this method, NPs with narrow size distribution and fine-tuned morphology can be fabricated. The seed growth method is among those well-acknowledged methods that synthesize high seeds and well-defined NPs [72,73]. A seed-mediated co-reduction approach is applied to simplify the complexity of synthesizing TMNs in defined and controlled morphology, size, and large-scale production. Au-Cu-Ag nanorods were successfully prepared in an oil phase via a seed-mediated core. The injection temperature and concentration of silver played an important role in controlling and regulating the desired morphology and state art of the TMNs. It has been confirmed that applying low temperature and silver concentration results in the formation of nanorods, however, at high temperature and concentration of silver precursor spherical nanostructure has been formed as demonstrated in Fig. 4 (a), and the formation of the nanorods was confirmed via TEM (Fig. 4(b)) [83]. When the injection temperature is raised to 120 °C, a mixture of rods, cubes, pentagons, and spherical NPs are formed, and the rod yield decrease from 78% to 17% (Fig. 4(c, d)). Further increasing the temperature to 180 °C, the rod yield decreases to 4%, and the majority of the NPs are changed to the sphere (Fig. 4(e)). Chen et al. [84] engineered PdCuM (M = Ir, Ru, Rh) nanocages (PdCuM NC) using seed-mediated growth strategy and the obtained catalyst used as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for HER and polyalcohol oxidation reactions under alkaline condition. The catalyst was synthesized by mixing Na2PdCl4, CuCl2.2H2O, W(CO)6, Fe(CH3COO)2, PVP, acetic acid, and DMF via sonicating until homogenized and PdCu NC are obtained. Once the PdCu NC is formed, the third metal source salts are added to form PdCuIr, PdCuRu, and PdCuRh NC as, shown in Fig. 5 (a). Finally, the electrocatalyst showed an outstanding performance in glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR), EGOR, and HER having good electrochemical durability and small overpotential. Similar studies of synthesizing the above TMN have been carried out by Jin et al. [85] in the form of 3D multi-metallic PdCuM (M = Ru, Rh, Ir) of Pd-based alloy ultrathin nanosheets (NSs), and employed for MOR. The seed-mediated growth method has been used to fabricate the 3D materials where PdCu NSs with the Pd/Cu (1:1 molar ratio) were fabricated first in advanced yield. Ethyl glycol dissolved in reducing agents (PVP, AA, and the third metal precursor) were added to obtain the ultrathin 3D PdCuM NSs after cooling (Fig. 5(b)). Lv et al. [86] synthesized size-dependent PdAgCu mesoporous nanospheres (MNSs) for ethanol electrooxidation. The PdAgCu was synthesized using a one-pot solution-phase approach using dioctadecyldimethylammonium chloride (DODAC) as a surfactant through the kinetic control-based surfactant-directing cooperative assembly. The DODAC has been used to control the reduction of the precursor. The content of the solvent (ethanol) was used to tune the size of the MNSs (Fig. 5(c)). 2.6 Other methods The manufacturing of multi-metallic nanomaterials is complex, nonequilibrium process. Therefore, efforts have done to solve such difficulties by applying a gas-phase synthesis that is eco-friendly and economical in synthesizing the TMNs consistently and effectively. Applying the individual Au, Pt, and Pd NPs growth, all three samples are co-sputtered to synthesis the Au-Pt-Pd NPs. All the three metals were allowed to nucleate individually where the Pd atom nucleate faster to form monometallic nuclei, and the Au and Pt further allowed to nucleate on it to produce consistently TMNs consistently [87]. Tsuji et al. [88] prepared Au@Ag@Cu trimetallic nanocrystals under oil-bath heating in the presence of the surfactant polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP). The Ag shells were allowed to overgrowth once the decahedral Au core seeds were established from the reduction of HAuCl4.4H2O in diethylene glycol. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is added during the mechanism of forming the decahedral Au@Ag nanocrystals. Finally, Cu shells were allowed to overgrown further on Au@Ag bimetallic nanocrystals to form the Au@Ag@Cu. Karthikeyan and Loganathan [89] fabricated Au-Pt-Ag and Au-Pd-Pt NPs nanotube, respectively, by microwave (MW) irradiation method using trisodium citrate and PVP as reductant and protecting/capping agents, respectively. Thus, the MW irradiation process is a fast and emerging technology for the synthesis of size distribution control TMNs than the conventional thermal heating process. Abazari et al. [90] prepared Pt/Pd/Fe TMNs using a water-in-oil microemulsion system of water/AOT/isooctane at room temperature. The microemulsion method is used to synthesize uniform NPs since the size of the TMNs is easily controlled by the droplets of the microemulsion (reverse micelles method). The micelles used in the synthesis are similar in size and lead to prepared uniform and homogeneous shapes and same size TMNs. The Pt/Pd/Fe TMNs was used for the reductive catalytic hydrodehalogenation of aryl and aliphatic halides and the TMNs were effective and efficient than the other bimetallic NPs (Pt/Pd, Pd/Fe, Pt/Fe). To summarize, different strategies have already been employed for the facile fabrication of TMNs with well-controlled morphologies. As clearly discussed in the above section, the methods such as hydrothermal [91], microemulsion, GRR [92], coprecipitation [93], microwave [94], and biological methods [82], have widely been used to synthesize the targeted material with desired morphology. However, these methods have several drawbacks due to the use of toxic reducing/capping agents (borohydrides, hydrazine, poly-N-vinylpyrrolidone) and toxic solvents that are not environmentally benign. The toxic chemicals may be absorbed on the surface of the TMNs, which largely hindered their use in medical applications. On the other hand, the physical method like sequential sputtering [95], lase-ablation [96], mechanical milling [97] uses physical forces to bring atoms together in the synthesis. And also, it is time-consuming and uses expensive equipment which requires high energy, temperature, pressure, tedious procedures that could result in the formation of hazardous byproducts during the synthesis. In order to alleviate the aforementioned drawbacks, researchers used a bioinspired method for the synthesis of the TMNs using some biological sources, including plant extracts, algae, bacteria, and fungi, as a bio-reductant without the addition of reagents [41,42]. For the synthesis of nanostructured materials with well-defined dimensions, the use of biomolecules that are present in the plant parts and microbials appears to be a versatile platform since they own some specific advantages such as non-toxicity, ease-to-scale-up, cheap, renewable, and well-defined dimensions [9,98]. Albeit the green method is promising, yet it has some drawbacks in the context of reproducibility, and the reaction mechanism involved is quite complex to be understood. 3 Application of TMNs for energy generation The urgent need for clean and renewable energy expenditures attracts the attention of researchers in terms of energy security and environmental concern. Due to the expansion of industrialization and rapid growth of population, the energy requirement of the globe is increasing every year. In this regard, catalytic chemistry plays a vital role in the synthesis of chemicals and materials, fuels, power conversion and generation, and environmental remediation activities [122]. The catalytic conversion, generation, and storage of useful energy resources from sustainable sources require the use of earth-abundant, low-cost material which can derive the required reaction. To date, a wide variety of low dimensional nanomaterials have already been become communicated while there is still a need for obtaining potentially active material that can catalyze different reactions. In recent studies, the TMNs have displayed a promising potential towards catalyzing some reactions such as HER, OER, ORR, MOR, EOR, etc. hence, and they are regarded as highly versatile materials for energy generation, conversion, and storage in a lithium-ion battery, catalyzing some electrochemical reactions. Moreover, they showed significant improvements in the way that energy is generated and stored, which is of paramount importance [123–128]. This section provides a general overview of the catalytic application of TMNs such as HER and alcohol oxidation reactions. 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) Pure hydrogen generation from different chemical reactions such as electrochemical water splitting has been the major scientific challenge that would still deserve further work in order to alleviate the energy crisis [125]. In general, the use of ternary metallic NP has been a major topic for many researchers, and it has already been demonstrated that H2 gas can be generated via catalyzing various kinds of reactions. The water splitting, hydrazine oxidation, and others are among those reactions that showed a great promise towards realizing hydrogen evolution. Given the current challenges in using noble metal electrodes such as Pt for HER, the multi-metallic nanostructures are sought to have some intriguing properties towards catalyzing H2 evolution and thereby replace those noble metals [46]. Mahmood et al. [129] successfully engineered an ultrathin PtAgCo trimetallic nanosheet (NS) for HER activity. The NS in the composition of PtAgCo2/C was stable and showed better performance than the other state arts. Thus, the Co-doped NS with 20% Pt exhibited the highest current density of 705 mA cm−2 at a potential of −400 mV. Further, the TMNS has been confirmed by the Tafel slope, and it exhibited 27–35 mV dec−1. The TMNS’s stability was also checked by CV between 0.0 and 0.1 vs. RHE at 50 mV s−1, which displayed continuously for 5000 cycles in 0.5 M H2SO4. A study by Jiao et al. [130] demonstrated the rational synthesis of Ni/Au/Co TMNs using a co-reduction from their corresponding metal precursors and NaBH4 as a reducing agent. The catalyst was tested for HER under an alkaline NaBH4 aqueous solution. The TMNs containing Ni, Au, Co with varying ratios of 30:30:40, 35:35:30, 40:40:20, and 45:45:10 was synthesized, and the corresponding average particle size was reported to be 3.1 ± 0.6 nm, 3.1 ± 0.9 nm, 2.5 ± 0.6 nm, and 1.9 ± 0.6 nm, respectively. Among these catalysts tested for HER the NP with 45:45:10 has displayed the highest catalytic activity (1170 mol-H2 per h per mol-M), which was about 1.5, 8, 10, and 14 times greater than that of Ni50Au50 BNPs, Au, Ni, and Co MNPs, respectively. The improved catalytic activity of the TMNs is attributed by the electronic charge transfer among the three metals due to their ionization energy difference. Chen et al. [131] synthesized the trimetallic platinum-nickel–cobalt hollow alloyed 3D multipods (HAMPs) via one-pot solvothermal method. It was demonstrated that the etching process and reaction temperatures played an essential role in the formation of the PtNiCo HAMPs. The PtNiCo HAMPS materials display excellent electrocatalytic activity under the alkaline condition for HER, which exhibit an overpotential of 20 mV at η 10 mA cm−2, compared to the bimetallic such as PtNi HAMPs (23 mV), PtCo NCs (24 mV), and Pt/C catalysts (38 mV). The trimetallic HAMPs showed lower overpotential. Similarly, the PtNiCo HAMPS exhibited a lower Tafel slope, and higher MA than the corresponding bi and monometallic NPs (Fig. 6 (d)). The main reason for the TMNs superior catalytic activity in HER was attributed to the unique structure, synergistic effects, and compositional advantage. In another study, PtAuCo trimetallic nanoalloy was successfully prepared via sequential digestive-reduction strategy as an efficient catalyst towards dehydrogenation of ammonia Borane (NH3BH3; AB) to produce H2 (Fig. 6(a)). The nanoalloy Pt76Au12Co12 was optimized with the highest turnover frequency (TOF) of 450 mol H2 min−1(mol metal)−1 and low activation energy (8.47 kJ mol−1) and 100% AB dehydrogenation in 36 s. interestingly, this nanoalloy was among those promising materials for hydrogen generation from AB with much better performance than the noble catalysts reported ever (Fig. 6(b, c)) [132]. AB has a hydrogen content of 19.6 wt % and its hydrolytic dehydrogenation can ideally yield 7.8 wt% of hydrogen. Similarly, hydrazine borane (HB, N2H4BH3) has also a hydrogen content of 15.4 wt%, which could be considered as a prominent hydrogen storage compound. It is worthy to note that the HB gives 12.2 wt% of hydrogen upon hydrolytic dehydrogenation and showed potential storage of hydrogen [133]. Reports by Wang et al. [134] showed that noble-metal-free NiFeMo nanocatalyst was able to catalyze hydrogen generation from the decomposition of hydrous hydrazine. The prepared Ni0.6Fe0.4Mo catalyst facilitates the complete decomposition of N2H4.H2O generating the gases (H2 and N2). Moreover, the catalyst has displayed good stability, recyclability, and selectivity and showing promising H2 generation without noticeable performance degradation after three cycles. Moreover, NiFePd nanoalloy was also used for hydrogen generation from alkaline hydrous hydrazine. The nanoalloy in the composition of Ni30Fe30Pd40 showed higher activity with 100% H2 selectivity, as confirmed from the gas chromatography analysis. The electrocatalyst can be recycled and reused several times without losing its catalytic activity. Further, the TOF value was found to be 21.5 h−1 at 323 K which is reasonably higher compared to most heterogeneous catalysts. The observed result was attributed to the electrical modification of Ni, Fe, and Pd in the alloy, high surface area, and small size of the nanoalloy [135]. Similarly, selective and durable TMNs PdNiRu nanochain with electrocatalytic surface area (ECSA) of 84.32 m2 g−1 has been investigated for hydrazine oxidation (N2H4 + 4OH– → N2 + H2O + 4e−) [136]. A Nanoengineered PdAgPt in the composition of Pd43Ag21Pt36 nanowheels has been studied by Lu and coworkers [8] for alcohol oxidation and HER applications. The 2D Pd43Ag21Pt36 nanoalloy exhibited better performance with the lowest overpotential of 9 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 which is better than the bimetallic Pd62Pt38 nanospheres (NS) (23 mV), Pd68Ag32 nanodendrites (ND) (176 mV), and commercial Pt/C (23 mV). The Pd43Ag21Pt36 nanoalloy recorded the smallest Tafel slope (19.6 mV dec−1) while the Pd68Ag32 ND, Pd62Pt38, and commercial Pt/C showed a Tafel slope of 101.4, 29.5, and 29.9 mV dec−1, respectively. The MA of the trimetallic nanoalloy was also better than the bimetallic ND, NS, and commercial Pt/C that results in 9.41/3.15/2.35 times higher than the bimetallic ND, NS, Pt/C. The superior HER activity of the 2D nanoalloy was attributed to the unique morphology and composition, additional active sites and enlarge ECSA which accelerates the electron transport and overall electronic change enhances the activity and stability. Furthermore, Fu and coworkers [137] studied IrNiFe TMNs as highly active bifunctional electrocatalysts for water splitting, as shown in Fig. 6(e, f). The as-synthesized IrNiFe NPs with a ratio of IrNi0.57Fe0.82 showed narrow size distribution in the average size of 2.2 nm, which is smaller than Ir (2.8 nm), IrNi0.68 (2.5 nm), and IrNi0.70Fe0.52 (2.4 nm), and slightly bigger than that of IrNi0.46Fe1.5 (2.0 nm) with a higher Fe content. The IrNi0.57Fe0.82 NPs possess the best HER activity, and only 24 mV overpotential was required to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2. For comparison, IrNi0.68 and Ir/C showed the lowest activity, 56, and 80 mV, respectively. Furthermore, the chronopotentiometry test of the IrNi0.57Fe0.82/C NP confirmed that, after continuous electrolysis of 20,000 s the catalyst does not change, whereas the overpotential increase by 17 mV, which shows the stability and superior durability of the nanostructure for HER under acidic condition (Fig. 6(f)). The narrow size distribution and synergistic electronic effect between Ir, Ni, and Fe improves the stability and performance of the TMN. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) The OER is a half-reaction of water splitting in the anode results in the formation of OO through the removal of 4e− from water (2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e−). Generally, the OER is complex and challenging than the HER due to the involvement of 4e- sequential proton-coupled electron transfer steps, sluggish OO bond formation, and multiple intermediates such as OOH*, OH*, O* [138]. Recent works by Zhu and coworkers [139] presented the synthesized Pt-Ir-Pd trimetallic cubic nanocages (TMCN) through two-step synthesis, that is, co-deposition of Pt and Ir atoms on the Pd nanocubes followed by selective removal of Pd cores via wet etching (Fig. 7 (a)). They have fabricated the TMCN with the atomic composition of Pt39Ir10Pd11 and well-defined facets. The as-synthesized TMCN was used as a dual electrocatalytic towards ORR and OER in acidic media. The OER performance of the TMCN was compared with the benchmarks of commercial Pt/C and Pt-Pd nanocages. A MA of 0.20 A mg−1 Pt+Ir at 1.53 V was recorded for the TMCN which was 16.7 and 4.3 times higher than those of Pt/C (0.012 A mg−1 Pt) and Pt-Pd (0.046 A mg−1 Pt+Pd), respectively. The polarization curve of the TMCN in comparison to the Pt/c and Pt-Pd is shown in (Fig. 7(b)). Furthermore, the Pt-Ir-Pd nanocage required 348 mV overpotential on the ORR which was below the commercial Pt/C (391 mV) and the Pt-Pd nanocage (396 mV) (Fig. 8 (d)). The authors revealed that the highly open structure and possible electronic coupling between Ir and Pt atoms of the TMCN was used for the better performance of the electrocatalyst. In another latest published paper, Khalid et al. [140] synthesized trifunctional FeCoNi alloy NPs via a simple one-pot chemical reaction of the metals of the salts and embedded on nitrogen-doped carbon shell (NC) and organic linkers. The nanoalloy in the composition of Fe1.0Co1.1Ni1.4-NC showed better catalytic activity towards OER. Both the Fe1.0Co1.1Ni1.4-NC and Fe1.0Co0.5Ni0.6-NC exhibited the best performance in OER with an overpotential of 270 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 while the other composition, Fe1.0Co4.4Ni6.5-NC, Fe1.0Co42.0Ni5.4-NC, RuO2, and FeNi-NC showed an overpotential of 340, 320, 440, and 290 mV, respectively (Fig. 7(c)). The stability of the Fe1.0Co1.1Ni1.4-NC catalyst was investigated by sweeping 1000 voltammogram cycle and chronoamperometric test of 21 h which virtually showed no loss of its performance and very little (6%) current attenuation was observed by the chronoamperometric test at 1.53 V vs. RHE, noticeably durable and stable catalyst for OER (Fig. 7(d)). An ultrathin NiFeCo Metal-Organic Framework nanosheet was used as electrocatalyst for OER in 0.1 M KOH, which showed an efficient performance with an overpotential of 216 mV at 100 mA cm−2, and a small Tafel slope (23.25 mV dec−1). The ECSA of this trimetallic nanosheet was larger than the bimetallic NPs and was stable under conditions tested [141]. Earlier studies have unveiled iron-rich trimetallic V–Co–Fe-343 NPs which were utilized as an electrocatalyst for OER [142]. These TMNs were synthesized with controllable pour sizes of 3.7 and 6.4 nm, and high surface area (232.1 m−2 g−1). The electrochemical measurements of the TMNs confirmed that the current density of the V–Co–Fe-343 electrocatalyst was 98.1 mA cm−2 at 1.58 V vs. RHE which was significantly higher than the bi and monometallic counterparts, the V-Co-Fe-343 electrocatalyst required lower overpotential (307 mV) to achieve the current density at 10 mA cm−2 along with a small Tafel slope of 36 mV dec−1. The trimetallic electrocatalysts towards ORR, HER required small overpotential and possesses a small Tafel slope than their corresponding bimetallic, monometallic and commercial Pt/C catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . A 3D pomegranate-like NiCoFe nanoassemblies (NAs) was reported by Wang and coworkers [143] for OER electrocatalysis. The NAs was synthesized by reduction in the feeding mole ratio of NiCl2/K3Co(CN)6/K3Fe(CN)6 to 3:2:1, 3:1:1, and 3:1:2 corresponding to the NiCoFe-321, NiCoFe-211, and NiCoFe-312 NAs. From the catalysts tested, the NiCoFe-211 catalyst demands the smallest over-potential (368 mV) to achieve the current density of 100 mA cm−2, in contrast with the others such as NiCoFe-321 (492 mV), NiCoFe-312 (542 mV), NiCo-NS (513 mV), NiFe (701 mV), and RuO2 catalyst (464 mV). The Tafel slope of the NiCoFe-211 was calculated to be 51.9 mV dec−1 providing fast electron transfer than the NiCo-NS (90.2 mV dec−1) and NiFe (128.7 mV dec−1). The enlarged specific surface area, abundant open channels of the porous structure, enriched oxygen vacancies derived from Fe into the NiCo facilitate the mass diffusion and release of generated oxygen gas, OH/H2O adsorption and enhance their electrical conductivity, regulating the electronic structures of the Ni/Co species to enhance the charge transport. The amorphous solid 3D interconnected structure was also effectively preventing the dissolution and even collapse of the electrocatalyst. 3.3 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The ORR is a multielectron reaction with several elementary steps and intermediates and complex reaction kinetics. Under acidic media, the ORR takes place either by direct four-electron reduction pathway to form water: H2O: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O or by the two-electron pathway to produce H2O2, followed by reduction of H2O2 to form water: O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2; H2O2 + 2H+ + e− → 2H2O [150]. In addition, the ORR can take place under basic electrolytes either by the direct four-electron reduction to produce OH– (O2 + H2O + 4e− → 4OH−) or two-electron reduction to generate HO2 – followed by subsequent reduction to OH− (O2 + H2O + 2e− → HO2 − + OH–: HO2 − + H2O + 2e− + OH−) [151]. The ORR involves the OO bond breaking and reduction of the adsorbed atomic oxygen [152]. In an early study by Fu et al. [153] the electrocatalytic activity of PdCuPt ternary nanodendrite was examined towards ORR in an acidic medium. The nanodendrite alloy was synthesized via GRR using a controlled amount of Pt precursor and a PdCu template in an aqueous solution. The TMNs with the ratio of Pd80Cu6Pt14 showed better catalytic performance for ORR, outperforming the commercial Pt/C and other state art electrocatalysts. Of particular note was that the Pd80Cu6Pt14 nanodendrite showed 14 times higher than the commercial Pt/C catalyst with an optimized composition of 1.73 AmgPt −1 at 0.85 V vs RHE. Further, the obtained TMNs have long-term stability. Thus, the Pd80Cu6Pt14 shows 14%, 23%, and 30% ECSA loss at first, third, and fifth cycles, while Pt/C catalysts present a substantial loss of 54% after the fifth cycle. Recently, Alfaro-López et al. [154] showed that a trimetallic Pt2NiCo/C could exhibit auspicious performance than that of Pt/C and the bimetallic PtNi/C and PtCo/C. Thus, the SA and MA of the TMN was measured that is 6.4 and 2.2 times higher than the benchmark Pt/C. The observed performance was due to the synergistic interaction within the TMNs. Finally, the TMN was confirmed to be durable and can be used as a promising cathode in the fuel cells. Jiang et al. [155] reported a trimetallic Au@PdPb core–shell nanowire (NWs) via a two-step water-bath method through gowning of the PdPb nanolayer on the surface of Au NWs (Fig. 8(a)). The formation and retention of the uniform wire-like structure of the catalyst was confirmed by the TEM image (Fig. 8(b)). The Au@PdPb NW has been used as an efficient electrocatalyst for ORR in an acidic medium. The half potential (E1/2) of the Au@PdPb NWs were 0.827 V whereas, that of Au@Pd NWs and commercial Pt black was 0.803 and 0.788 V, respectively (Fig. 8(c)). The MA and SA of the Au@PdPb NW was measured to 233.44 mA mg−1 and 4.09 mA cm−2 at 0.85 V, which was 1.68 and 1.44 times higher than Au@Pd NWs (139.16 mA mg−1 and 2.84 mA cm−2) and 2.22 and 19.0-fold higher than the commercial Pt black (105.35 mA mg−1 and 2.15 mA cm−2). The introduction of Au as a core modifies the electronic structure of the PdPb shell which results in decreasing the adsorption strength of the oxygen species on the surface of Au@PdPb, and thereby enhancing the ORR activity. Moreover, Guo et al. [156] fabricated FePtM/FePt (M = Pd, Au) nanowires (NWs) using a seed-mediated synthesis approach for electrocatalytic ORR application. The performance of the TMNs was dependent on the core-composition of FePtM. The core/shell FePtM/FePt was found to be highly active and durable when compared with other NW alloys and Pt/C for the ORR. The FePtPd/FePt NWs exhibited 3.47 mA cm−2 and 1.68 A mgPt −1 vs. Ag/AgCl of SA and MA, respectively, which is better than the other NWs, including FePtAu/FePt, FePt, and commercial Pt/C (Fig. 8(e, f)). Moreover, the TMNs with novel core–shell morphologies have attracted researchers where the obtained morphology played a prominent role in catalyzing some reactions. For instance, Eid et al. [157] designed a 3D dendritic nanocage containing PtPdRu TMN and investigated its catalyzed activity towards ORR. The as-synthesized dendritic nanocage exhibited an ECSA of 96.8 m2 g−1 which was higher than the Pt/C (58.2) and PtPdRu nanodendrites (64.4 m2 g−1). The dendritic nanocage possessed 2.9 and 2.61 mA cm−2 of SA and MA, respectively, which was 1.81 and 2.08-fold higher than the nanodendrites and 8.78 and 14.1 times higher than the Pt/C, respectively (Fig. 8(g)). Thus, the novel TMN with porous dendritic shell was highly active and durable during the ORR due to their composition, shape, and electron mobility. In another study, a Ti-Au@Pt/C core–shell TMN was rationally designed for ORR. The TMNs performed better than the bimetallic Au@Pt and the commercial Pt/C showing an overall 15- and 5-fold higher improvements in MA and SA activity, respectively, when compared to Pt owing to the protected Ti oxide located on the edge and vertex sites and stable Pt shells, the catalyst exhibited excellent durability and showed similar performance even after 10,000 potential cycles (Fig. 8(h, i)) [158]. Li et al. [159] fabricated Au@PdPt core–shell NP with an ultrathin bimetallic PtPd-skin surface for ORR in acidic media. The TMN with the ratio of Au@Pd1.19Pt1 showed superior electrocatalytic activity in the cathodic fuel cell with the SA of 3.06 mA cm−2, which was 1.31 times higher than the Pt/C and much higher than the Au@PdPt. The MA of Au@Pd1.19Pt1 was 598.53 mA mg−1 Pt, 6.1-fold higher than Pt/C (98.30 mA mg−1 Pt). Of note was that the catalytic activity of the TMN was unchanged after 3000 potential cycles under a potential window of 0.1 and 0.7 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Apart from the core–shell, NPs, and nanocage morphologies, various researchers designed TMNs with unique morphologies and intriguing catalytic properties. For instance, Lokanathan and coworkers [160] synthesized PtNiCo nanoflowers (NF) as an ideal electrocatalyst for ORR. The NF displayed a MA and SA of 543.7 mA mg−1 Pt and 2.47 mA cm−2 pt, respectively, which is 3.5 and 12.35-fold higher than the commercial Pt/C. According to the authors, the observed performance was due to the strain effect created by Ni and Co atoms in the Pt that influence the Pt electronic structure (d-band downshift). The ECSA of the TMNs after 10 k cycles was 43.4 m2 g−1 Pt which means 97% of its initial value was retained. Moreover, Cruz-Martı́nez et al. [161] synthesized an efficient NiPdPt/C TMNs synthetic chemical method and investigated its electrocatalytic property towards ORR under an acidic medium. The designed TMN catalyst exhibited an ECSA of 80.78 ± 3.5 m2 g−1 Pt surpassing the benchmark Pt/C (58.70 m2 g−1 Pt). Additionally, this material displayed reasonable higher performance with 250.8 ± 8.7 µA cm−2 Pt and 202.3 ± 2 mA mg−1 Pt of SA and MA, respectively, which is better than the commercial Pt/C (206.4 µA cm−2 Pt and 121.2 mA mg−1 Pt) at 0.9 V vs NHE. Finally, the electrocatalyst was able to show good stability. A very recent study by Wang et al. [162] reported an ordered structure of PtCoFe alloy for electrocatalytic application towards ORR. The addition of the third metal (Fe) to the PtCo allows more electron transfer towards Pt than the Co in the PtCo alloy (Fig. 9 (a, b)). Thus, the strong charge transfer can downshift the d-band center of Pt, which can influence the interaction between the adsorbed oxygenated species and active Pt sites that results in the improved electrocatalytic performance of the PtCoFe towards ORR. In the mentioned system, the TMNs has possessed a MA of 1.43 AmgPt −1 which was 1.47 and 8.41 times higher than the PtCo and Pt/C, respectively. Similarly, the SA of the PtCoFe was 2.23 mA cm−2. However, SA values of 1.34 mA cm−2 and 0.23 mA cm−2 were obtained from PtCo and the commercial Pt/C, respectively (Fig. 9(c, d)). A comparison of TMNs with their monometallic and bimetallic systems towards ORR is summarized in Table 3 . 3.4 Alcohol oxidations Recently, the electrocatalytic oxidation of alcohol has received considerable attention due to its potential use as a renewable energy source in portable electronic devices, storage, and small electrical appliance due to their higher energy density, high efficiency, and mild operation conversions [165]. Until now, noble metal electrodes like Pt have been used in the oxidation reactions however, using Pt as an electrode in the fuel cell has several bottlenecks, such as its rareness, poisoning by CO and high overpotential. Therefore, designing and developing a catalyst that is easily available (earth-abundant metals) that can be used for the complete oxidation of the liquid fuels (methanol, ethanol, and glycerol) without leaching or poisoning in the fuel is imperative [166]. In this regard, recent studies have witnessed that the oxidation of alcohols such as methanol, ethanol, and polyalcohols could be catalyzed by the state-of-the-art functional ternary nanostructures. In contrast to those non-novel metal-based ternary metals, the alloys containing Pt along with other metals like Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn have widely been investigated. However, the catalysis is still complicated by uncontrolled leaching of the metal themselves and leads to incomplete oxidation. Importantly, the organic substrates that were the focuses of this investigation are liquid fuels like formic acid, methanol, glycols, and ethanol, which have higher energy density than gaseous hydrogen. However, the problem associated with these liquids is, their oxidation is not effective to undergo complete conversion to CO2 [167–170]. To date, various electrocatalysts have been playing a critical function in lowering the energy barrier to minimize the electrochemical potential which is required to derive the chemical reaction [167–169,171]. Here, the multi-metallic NPs are among those catalysts with an intriguing feature, which are expected to supplement the benchmark through solving the drawbacks [48,172–175]. On one hand, the incorporation of the third metal to the bimetallic once changes the surface of the electronic structure of the metals which enables to tune the binding energy between the electrocatalyst and intermediates at the core or alloy which tolerates the CO in the electrooxidation reactions [176,177]. On the other hand, the generally acceptable synthetic routes for obtaining TMNs offered the opportunity of introducing a trace amount of novel metals, thereby enhancing the stability and activity. Very recently, Zhu and coworkers [178] synthesized PtPbBi hexagonal NPs (HNPs) via a simple solvothermal method and studied their potential towards the electrocatalytic EOR and EGOR (Fig. 10 (a)). The PtPbBi HNPs showed excellent catalytic activity, providing 8870 mA mg−1 Pt and 10,225 mA mg−1 Pt MA corresponding to EOR and EGOR, respectively. When compared with the Pt/C, the catalyst showed nearly 12.7 and 1.85-fold greater MA for the respective EOR and EGOR (Fig. 10(b, c)). Moreover, The HNPs were durable, and 42.7% of its MA was retained after the continuous chronoamperometric test (3600 s) for EGOR. This unprecedented performance could be attributed to the electron transfer among the three metals that weaken the CO and enhance the OH adsorption by removing the toxic intermediates. The addition of Pd and Bi leads to downward shift of the Pt d-band center, which contributes to the oxidation of CO adsorbed on the Pt surface. A recent work by Chen and coworkers [179] reported the synthesis of hollow interior and porous dendritic outer morphology of NiPtPd TMNs via GRR method for MOR electrocatalyst (Fig. 10(d, e)). The hollow nanocrystals (HNCs) NiPtPd was active and CO-tolerant which exhibited 10.68 mA cm−2 and 3.95 A.mg Pd+Pt −1 of SA and MA, respectively, that is 4.2 and 4.5 times higher than the commercial Pt/C (Fig. 10(f)). The chronoamperometry (CA) and CO-stripping tests showed high tolerance of CO better than those of bimetallic and Pt/C electrodes. The NiPtPd-HNCs retained 68% of the current density of the MOR after 2000 CVs cycles. Owing to some special advantages such as low price, high energy density, and its simplicity in storage and transportation of its source (methanol), direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) reactions have been the topic of many researchers. In general, the oxidation of methanol takes place at the anode, and the anodic and cathodic reactions are given in Eqs. (1)–(3). (1) Anode reaction: CH 3 OH l + H 2 O → CO 2 g + 6 H aq + + 6 e - (2) Cathode reaction: 3 / 2 O 2 g + 6 H aq + + 6 e - → 3 H 2 O l (3) Overall reaction: CH 2 OH l + 3 / 2 O 2 g → CO 2 g + 2 H 2 O l Lan et al. [180] studied the catalytic performance of Pt60Ni3Cu37 and Pt60Ni13Cu27 nanoalloys towards MOR in an acidic medium. The calculated ECSA of Pt60Ni3Cu37, Pt60Ni13Cu27, Pt55Cu45, and commercial Pt/C was found 33.4, 25.2, 20.0, and 19.8 m2 g−1, respectively. Among the catalyst using 0.5 M solution, the MA of Pt60Ni3Cu37 and Pt60Ni13Cu27 was found to be 3.6/5.3 and 2.4/3.5 times greater than the porous Pt55Cu45 nanoalloys/commercial Pt black. Additionally, the value of the values of MA of Pt60Ni3Cu37 and Pt60Ni13Cu27 nanoalloys was significantly raised to 1.3 and 0.78 A mgPt −1 which was 4.3/2.6 and 2.6/1.7 times higher than the Pt55Cu45 (0.3 A mgPt −1)/Pt/C (0.45 AmgPt -1), respectively, at 0.5 M of methanol. The CA test for 3600 s confirmed that only 12% Pt60Ni3Cu37 was lost, whereas, Pt/C had lost 27% of its activity in MOR. Lan et al. [181] also studied the electrocatalytic activity of the defect-rich PtPdCu nanoalloys toward methanol, ethanol, and glycol oxidation in acidic conditions. The SA and MA of the Pt34Pd33Cu33 NA/commercial Pt/black towards methanol, ethanol, and glycol oxidation was found to be 3.29/0.69, 0.31/0.25, 0.50/0.30 mA cm−2, and 0.66/0.47, 0.18/0.19, and 0.17/0.11 A mg−1 Pt, respectively, at 0.5 V. The peak current density of the Pt34Pd33Cu33 nanoalloys was 2.2 times (for methanol), 1.2 times (for ethanol), and 2.1 times (for glycol) greater than that of commercial Pt/black. Further, the current density of the TMNs (nanoalloy) was found 2.4 times (for methanol), 1.8 times (for ethanol), and 3.0 times (for glycol) greater than the commercial Pt/black after 1000 cycles due to the synergistic effect [182]. In an earlier study, a core–shell structure of Au/CuPt TMNs has been synthesized and studied for MOR and ORR electrocatalysis, where the TMNs exhibited stable, durable, and superior catalytic performance having the electropositive Au in the core to protect Pt from easily oxidizing and CO poisoning. Thus, the Au/CuPt TMNs were effective in the MOR (anode catalyst and ORR (cathode catalyst) fuel cells [183]. A recent work by Peng and coworkers [184] has also unveiled novel carbon-supported PtPdCr/C ternary alloy NPs for methanol oxidation. They confirmed that the PtPdCr/C electrocatalyst was durable and stable than the PrRu/C and Pt/C when analyzed by accelerated durability test and CA. Further, the TMNs showed higher performance in terms of MA (960 mA.mg-1 Pt) when compared with PtRu/C (725 mA mg−1 Pt) and Pt/C (581 mA mg−1 Pt). The observed unprecedented performance was due to the change in the binding energy of Pt and the synergistic effect of Pd and Cr atoms. In a similar study by Xu et al. [185] the rational synthesis and electrocatalytic activity of highly open PdAuAg nanocages against EGOR and GOR were demonstrated. Under the conditions tested, TMNs Pd1Au1Ag1 exhibited higher MA (5676.1 mA mg−1), which surpass the d1Ag1, Au1Ag1, and Pd/C catalyst by 1.8, 2.6, and 6.8 folds, respectively. Similarly, the Pd1Au1Ag1 nanocage performed the highest electrocatalytic activity for GOR with the MA of 7578.2 mA mg−1, which was 1.7, 2.2, and 7.5 times higher than the Pa1Ag1, Au1Ag1, and commercial Pd/C, respectively, and other state arts Pd2Au1Ag1 and Pd1Au2Ag1 nanocages. In another work of the same group [186] a bowl-like PtAuAg nanocages electrocatalyst was prepared by GRR method. This catalyst showed promising potentials for electrocatalyzing liquid fuel EGOR with the MA is being 6357.1 mA mg−1 which was 5.5, 2.1, and 1.5-fold higher than the Pt/C, AuAg, and PtAg, respectively. The PtAuAg nanocage possessed long-term stability with the highest retained MA of 2218.6 mA mg−1 and normalized current of 34.9% after successive 500 CV cycles. In another related study, Zhai and coworkers [187] engineered a hexagonal PtCuCo nanocrystal for electrooxidation of ethylene glycerol and glycerol. They have reported an outstanding performance of 4926.4 and 3519.9 mA mg−1 MA corresponding to EGOR and GOR, respectively, which was relatively higher when compared with the Pt/C (1161.2 mA mg−1) and bimetallic electrocatalyst. Furthermore, this hexagonal TMNs has retained its MA and normalized percentage to 2740.6 mA mg−1 and 55.7% and 1893.7 mA mg−1 and 53.8% for the corresponding to EGOR and GOR, respectively, after 500 cycles of CV. However, the commercial Pt/C, PtCo, and PtCu catalysts retained only 14.2, 30.3, and 39.8%, respectively, of their performance under the same circumstance. The unique hexagonal shape, abundant surface area, electronic effect among the metals played the major role to improve the durability and performance of the TMNs. EOR is more complex than GOR, MOR, and EGOR processes. Ethanol is not completely converted to CO2 by the 12 e− oxidations rather to other products such as acetaldehyde and acetic acid when carried out under acidic conditions and to acetate under alkaline conditions. Therefore, the new design of novel nanostructured materials that could potentially facilitate the cleavage of the CC bond and the complete oxidation of ethanol to CO2 is under intensive investigation (CH3CH2OH + 3H2O → 2CO2 + 12H+ + 12e−) [188]. In order to improve the catalytic activity of the Pt and Pd catalysts, second or third metal or metal oxide is required as a promotor for the cleavage of CC bonds [189]. Various ternary electrocatalysts such as PtPdAu (3–4.5 nm), Pt-Ru-Sn/C (5.8–7 nm), and Au-Pd@Pd) core–shell nanoflowers have already been used for catalyzing ethanol oxidation and provide promising MA and SA. These TMNs catalysts were also durable and CO tolerant in the EOR fuel cell compared with the commercial Pd/C and Pt/C [190–192]. Recently, Sui et al. [193] fabricated a ternary Au@PdNi core–shell NP (Au@PdNi CSNP) via Co-reduction. The ECSA of the as-synthesized Au@PdNi CSNP was calculated to 50.2 m2 g−1. The NP with Au@(PdNi)20 CSNP exhibited higher catalytic performance than the other stoichiometric ratio counter components. Thus, the Au@(PdNi)20 CSNP has performed a MA of 5891 mA mgPd −1, which is 9.48 times higher than the Pd/C electrode. The stability of the core–shell structure electrocatalyst was also measured by chronoamperometry for the successive 3600 s. Site-selective formation of Au/Ag/Pt hetero-nanostructures (AAPHNs) was prepared via co-reduction of the metal precursors using L-AA as a reducing agent and Au nanorods as a seed through a stepwise formation of Au@Au, Au@Au/Pt, Au@AgPt hetero-nanostructures, and AAPHNs (Fig. 11 (a)). The AAPHNs material was used for MOR under acidic and basic conditions. The MA and SA of the AAPHNs were much higher than the Au@AgPt preliminary hetero-nanostructures and Pt/C (Fig. 11(b)) [68]. In another recent study, Wang et al. [194] engineered a top-rank ultrathin 2D PdPtCu TMN for EOR. The edge-richest 9.0-nm-Pd61Pt22Cu17 nanoring has been synthesized in a one-pot synthesis by heating DMF solution with Pd(acac), Pt(acac), and Cu(acac) as a metal precursor with the addition of KBr and Mo(Co)6 (Fig. 11(c)). A uniform hexagonal nanoring with almost 100% yield of the products has been obtained as confirmed by TEM (Fig. 11(d)). The trimetallic nanoring (TNR) was synthesized in an average edge length and width of 9.0 nm and 2.7 nm, respectively. Thus, the high-quality Pd dominant ultrathin nanoring performed a MA of 20.2, 15, and 8.7 times, higher than the commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst, 7.3-nm-Pd62Pt16Cu20, ND 16.5-nm-Pd61Pt18Cu21 trimetallic nanosheets (TNSs), respectively, in EOR, which can solve the difficulty of 12 electrons transform, CC bond breaking, and succeeding CO removal (Fig. 11(e)). Chronoamperometric (i-t) tests have been conducted to measure the durability of the Pd richest 9.0-nm-Pd61Pt22Cu17 TNRs/C, which maintains its superior activity and structural integrity, as shown in Fig. 11(f). A PtPdCu nanodendrites (NDs) has been reported for the complete ethanol oxidation due to its high surface area that provides an abundant active site. The PtPdCu NDs exhibited 5.59 A mg−1 PtPd and 15.82 mA cm−2 of MA and SA, respectively, toward EOR, which means 6.4 and 3.6 times higher than the commercial Pt/C. The NDs also showed promising durability, CO anti-poisoning, CC bond cleavage to a C1 pathway [195]. A ternary PdPtNi nanostructure (NSs) with a spiny surface was designed using a one-pot solvothermal method. The NSs was applied for electrocatalytic application towards EOR under alkaline medium. The electronic nature of Pt was altered due to the introduction of Ni which indicates a strong interaction among Pd, Pt and Ni due to their electronegative difference. The d-band center of Pt was also changed due to the incorporation of Ni which results in bond strength modification of the active species in the surface accelerating the removal of adsorbed carbonaceous intermediates via synergistic effect. Furthermore, the PdPtNi possessed a MA of 1195.81 mA mg−1 while the PdPt, PtNi, PdNi, and Pt black provide a MA of 369.55, 695.98, 517.21, and 110.58 mA mg−1, respectively. CA and CV measurements of the NSs confirmed the tolerance and stability of the electrocatalyst. In addition, TEM image analysis of the CA measurement of the NSs towards the EOR also confirmed that no change was observed compared to the shapes before the stability test [196]. A comparison report on the performances of TMNs, bi, and monometallic nanostructures is shown in Table 4 . Luo et al. [18] synthesized 2D Pd-Fe-Pt nanomeshes (NMs) by a facile wet-chemical reaction, where Pd(acac)2, Pt(acac)2, and Fe2(CO)9 were used as metal precursors for fuel electrooxidations towards MOR, EOR, and FAOR. The NMs in the proportion of Pd59Fe27Pt14 provides a MA of 1.61, 0.56, and 2.45 AmgPt −1 towards MOR, EOR, and FAOR fuel electrooxidations, which was 7.3-fold, 3.1-fold, and 7.6-fold higher than the commercial Pt/C, respectively. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations confirmed that, the spin regulation modifies the tuning of electronic interactions in the d-orbital and the oxygen-containing adsorbents and intermediates (OHads). Thus, the binding energy of the Pd59Fe27Pt14 NMs is negatively shifted by ~0.50 eV compared with the commercial Pt/C due to the interactions of the three metals which results to weaker binding between Pt and COads and promoting easy release of COads from Pt. In another work by Zhang et al. [197], it was also confirmed that the multi-branched PdRuCu nanoassemblies (NAs) exhibited 4.14, 1.73, and 6.62 times greater MA than the PdRu NAs, PdCu NAs, and Pd black towards the EOR. In addition, it showed an improved SA, exceeding PdRu NAs, PdCu NAs, and Pd black by 1.33, 1.29-, and 2.09-folds, respectively. At the same time, the PdRuCu showed superior activity towards the ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) than the mono and bimetallic counterparts. The presence of numerous defects, multiple branch structures, increased surface area accelerates the mass/electron transfer rate to improve the catalytic performance and durability of the PdRuCu NAs. 3.5 Formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) In recent years, the oxidation of formic acid at the anode of the direct formic acid fuel cells (DFAFCs) has been the topic for many researchers. DFAFs are alternative power sources since they possessed an electromotive force of (EMF = 1.45 V), which is higher than the direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs, EMF = 1.21 V) and hydrogen fuel cells (EMF = 1.23 V) [202]. The aqueous solution of formic acid is non-explosive, non-combustible, and recognized as safe and simplistic to handling when compared with liquid methanol [203]. The electrooxidation of this acid using Pt is not practical due to the CO poisoning effect, while the Pd electrocatalyst showed good catalytic activity at a lower temperature. Despite its comparative advantage over Pt, the Pd catalyst still need further improvement via combining it with other metals (Ir, Cu, and others) or nonmetals (like S, P, or N) to enhance its activity and stability [204]. The FAOR has a dual-path reaction mechanism. The first one is direct dehydrogenation of formic acid to give CO2 (Eqs. (4)–(6)). The second path is through the dehydration pathway, where formic acid is converted to CO and H2O. The latter route is accompanied by the releases of a high amount of CO that may inhibit the Pt electrocatalyst by adsorbing on its active site. Thus, a multi-metallic electrocatalyst is required for the direct dehydrogenation pathway of the FAOR [205]. (4) Anode reaction: HCOO l → CO 2 g + 2 H aq + + 2 e - (5) Cathode reaction: 1 / 2 O 2 g + 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 O l (6) Overall reaction: HCOOH l + 1 / 2 O 2 g → CO 2 g + H 2 O l In contrast with the monometallic, bimetallic NPs, and commercial materials, the TMNs exhibited excellent catalytic activities towards FAOR due to their synergistic effects, effective and successive electronic effect, and charge transfer. These days, new insight into the designing of the advanced materials of nanoscale catalysts in the electrocatalyst with hollow and core/shell structure of multicomponent have gained a deep attention [179]. For example, A core–shell Ru@AuPt nanostructure has been prepared using a sequential reduction method and studied their potential towards electrocatalytic FAOR. The NPs were prepared in different compositions like Ru@(Au5Pt5)0.5, Ru@(Au5Pt5), and Ru@(Au5Pt5)1.5. Among these, the Ru@(Au5Pt5) nanostructure exhibited 1.2 A mg−1 and 4.14 mA cm−2 of MA and SA, respectively, which indicates 5.8 and 3.5, and 6.5 and 3.5-fold improvement when compared to the bimetallic Ru@Pt and Au5Pt5 alloys, respectively. Additionally, this ternary core–shell nanostructure outperforms the Pt/C by 52 and 17 folds in terms of its MA and SA. The electrocatalyst showed excellent resistance to CO poisoning and promising performance towards the electrooxidation of FAOR [173]. Hu et al. [206] investigated the catalytic performance of a Pd-based bi and TMNs such as (Pd/C, PdNi/C, PdCu/C, and PdNiCu/C alloy) for FAOR electrocatalytic activity. It was demonstrated that the PdNiCu/C exhibited a MA of 792 mA mgPd −1 than the Pd/C (212), PdCu/C (645), and PdNi/C (396). Similarly, the TMN exhibited the highest current density than the other alloys. The highest performance was attributed to the shift in d-band center away from the Fermi level, which results in the charge transfer from Pd to Ni or Cu metals, the bond strength between the adsorbate and Pd surface is weakened. Further, composition-dependent electrocatalysts such as ternary carbon-supported Pd-Cu-Fe and PdAuCo TMNs have been used for FAOR with enhanced activity and durability [207,208]. External and internal interface-controlled trimetallic PtCuNi nanoframes (NFs) have been fabricated via one-pot method towards MOR and FAOR. More than 90% of the PtCuNi concave (ec-NFs) was confirmed to face-to-face with 15 nm. The external structure of the NFs evolves from concave to branch. The PtCuNi branch NFs (PtCuNi eb-NFs) exhibit a multi-hierarchical structure with a branch diameter of 8 nm and PtCuNi hexapod NFs (PtCuNi eh-NFs, has been obtained when the amount of NaI was raised to 602.6 mg (Fig. 12 (a–c)). Therefore, the tunable external structure of the NFs exhibited to increase in their performance towards FAOR comparing to the benchmark Pt/C as shown Fig. 12(d–f)). The abundance of unsaturated sites of the high-index facets and vacancy of the external surface play a role in the improved electrocatalytic activity [20]. Carbon supported NiAuPd/C was fabricated through a co-reduction method for hydrogen generation from formic acid in an aqueous solution. The NP in the ratio of Ni0.40Au0.15 Pd0.45/C exhibited excellent catalytic activity with 100% hydrogen selectivity, and 73% of the fatty acid can be converted to CO2 + H2 in 600 min. The dehydrogenation reaction was carried out at room temperature without additives [209]. In another study, a PdAgCo/C TMNs were synthesized by Liu et al. [210], which exhibited better catalytic activity for FAOR. The catalytic activity of this TMNs was 1133.249 mA mgPd −1, which was 2.4 and 1.7 times higher than the Pd/C (483.563 mA mgPd −1) and the bimetallic PdAg/C (680.741 mA mgPd −1), respectively. In 2019, Khan [211] prepared TMNs, Pd-Ag-Fe, Fe-Pd-Ag, and Fe-Ag-Pd with capsules-like morphology through seedless and step-wise simultaneous chemical reduction. The as-synthesized TMNs were used for formic acid degradation. The Fe-Ag-Pd nanostructure configuration exhibited maximum catalytic activity resulting in TOF of 75 moles H2 per mole of catalyst/h, and activation energy (E a) of 51.6 kJ/mol. Further, the TMNs (Fe-Ag-Pd) were recycled for six consecutive cycles without losing their catalytic efficiency. Apart from this reaction, the carbon-supported PdNiAg trimetallic heterogeneous catalyst has also displayed very interesting achievement for formic acid decomposition reaction [212]. The trimetallic nanocatalyst with the composition of Pd0.58Ni0.18Ag0.24/C was found to exhibit high selectivity and activity towards the dehydrogenation of formic acid. The catalyst showed excellent selectivity (~100%) and higher activity with a TOF value of 85 moles of H2 mole catalyst−1h−1 at 50 °C. The Pd0.58Ni0.18Ag0.24 /C was exceptionally stable against agglomeration, leaching, and CO poisoning, which makes it reusable in formic acid dehydrogenation. It retains almost its inherent activity (>94%) even at the 5th catalytic run. A PtAuRu nanostructure (NSs) with porous and perpendicular pore channels has been employed for FAOR. The PtAuRu NSs displayed 1044.1 mA mg−1 and 14.5 mA cm−2 of MA and SA, respectively, while the PtAu, PtRu, and Pt/C exhibited, 570.6/10.7, 438.1/8.8, and 254.5/6.5 of MA/SA, respectively. The successive CVs of 500 cycles measurements confirmed its long-term stability. The abundance of active surface area, charge transfer, electronic, and synergistic effects originated from Pt, Au, and Ru accounts for the enhanced the catalytic activity and selectivity [213]. The performance of TMNs towards FAOR in comparison to the mono and bimetallic nanostructures is summarized in Table 5 . In summary, the research in the last few years have witnessed the potential of ternary nanostructures containing 3 different metals that could bring an interesting feature in catalysis. The Pt-based alloys are among the widely studied trimetallic nanoarchitectures where they showed promising potential to derive some reactions such as HER, OER, ORR, EOR, MOR, and FAOR (Fig. 13 ). Interestingly, the use of a small amount of Pt combined with some other bi-metallic nanostructures is of wise choice that can help in solving the limitation of using Pt electrode alone as an electrocatalyst. Albeit quite interesting progress have already been made in some specific reactions, there seems a room to widely use this family of catalyst to derive other organic reactions. 4 Conclusions and prospects The synthesis of metal NPs for diverse applications has been studied extensively in the last few decades. The NPs are engineered and manipulated in different morphological architectures by introducing alloying components to increase their performance. Synthesizing of multi-metallic alloys or core-shells array is a great deal of obtaining metallic nanocrystals, nanowires, dendritic, nanotubes, and core–shell nanostructures. Various strategies are applied to fabricate the TMNs mostly the bottom-up approach either chemically or biologically. TMNs own unique properties and superior performances due to the synergistic effect of the three metals. The applications of the TMNs catalysts highly depend on their structure/morphology and composition of the monometallic which must be controlled by the synthesis parameters. The TMNs showed a promised application in the electrocatalysis such as hydrogen generation, methanol/ethanol, and formic acid oxidations, and ORR. Thus, the use of the TMNs improves the performance of the anode catalyst in the hydrocarbon oxidation (Methanol, ethanol, glycol, formic acid) via replacing the low performance and noble Pt electrode, which was easily challenged by CO poisoning. The TMNs have superior performance, selectivity, stability or durability, and recyclability than the corresponding mono and bimetallic NPs catalysts. Until now, the TMNS showed better catalytic activity, stability, durability, and recyclability than their corresponding mono and bimetallic nanostructures. However, there are still challenges that must be addressed and investigated well in order to advance their usage towards energy conversion. As for the synthesis, there is a difficulty in precisely controlling the compositional ratio of the metals via the chemical methods which have different reduction kinetics of the metallic precursors, the elucidation of the dominant synergistic effect in the ternary system is till challenging [217]. The lack of reproducible, scalable, and continuous synthetic procedures limits the TMNs from being commercialized. Hence, intensive work is required to synthesize TMNs with desired size, shape, and morphology which also own strong electronic interaction, uniform active sites, modified atomic distance as well as high enthalpy of mixing which improves their electrocatalytic performance [218]. Additional efforts should be given for the modification of TMNS which can be offered high performance and long-term stability considering the defects, ligand, electronic, strain, interfacial, and modification of the surface area. The optimizing of surface and interfacial structures in TMNs is very crucial. There are often undesirable structural degradation and poor stability in the TMNs which emanate from improperly optimized surface and interfacial structures. Though challenging, these seems a point for additional investigation which would deserve further research. Given their auspicious performance and stability, especially for anodic electrocatalytic process, more theoretical efforts are required to unveil the rationale behind the excellent performance and stability. Moreover, a combination of theoretical calculations and operando spectroscopic analysis could be helpful to extract more about the nature of the electrocatalyst and reaction progress. coredata.dc:description: The advancement and growth of nanotechnology lead to realizing new and novel multi-metallic nanostructures with well-defined sizes and morphology, resulting in an improvement in their performance in various catalytic applications. The trimetallic nanostructured materials are synthesized and designed in different architectures for energy conversion electrocatalysis. The as-synthesized trimetallic nanostructures have found unique physiochemical properties due to the synergistic combination of the three different metals in their structures. A vast array of approaches such as hydrothermal, solvothermal, seed-growth, galvanic replacement reaction, biological, and other methods are employed to synthesize the trimetallic nanostructures. Noteworthy, the trimetallic nanostructures showed better performance and durability in the electrocatalytic fuel cells. In the present review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent strategies employed for synthesizing trimetallic nanostructures and their energy-related applications. With a particular focus on hydrogen evolution, alcohol oxidations, oxygen evolution, and others, we highlight the latest achievements in the field.
